body.p: The SolidFire storage system is an interconnection of hardware and software designed for complete automation and management of an entire SolidFire storage system.
SolidFire uses the following defintions for Node and Cluster:

dlentry.dd: Each node is a collection of Solid State Drivers (SSD). Each storage node comes with CPU, networking, cache and storage resources. The storage node resources are pooled into a cluster of nodes.

A cluster is the hub of a SolidFire Storage system and is made up of a collection of nodes. You must have at least four nodes in a cluster. in order for SolidFire storage efficiencies to be implemented correctly. A cluster appears on the network as a single logical group and can then be accessed as block storage. Although only four nodes are required, five or more nodes are recommended.

body.p: SolidFire relies on Cinder, an OpenStack service that manages the creation, attaching, and detaching of block storage volumes between a storage system like SolidFire and different host servers. The Helion third-party hardware integration team tested integrating SolidFire as a single backend with .

If you already have SolidFire deployed in your environment and want to integrate its storage with , you can use this document to understand how testers have successfully completed the process. The process involves meeting all of the hardware and network requirements, and configuring SolidFire as a single back-end. Additionally, this topic provides sample test scenarios that have been used to verify integration with Helion OpenStack.
